Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Ceramic Based Nanocomposite Films and Sensors for Life Cycle Monitoring of Materials in High Temperature Harsh Environments
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Significant cost savings can be achieved by optimizing the maintenance and servicing of machinery that is used in high temperature harsh industrial environments, such as those found in turbine engines, petrochemical processing plants, combustion burners, power plant boilers, oil/gas drilling, metals smelting and refining, and ceramic manufacturing. Unfortunately, currently available thin film materials rapidly degrade in the high temperature harsh conditions of interest to the high temperature industry sector, making sensors and other monitoring devices unstable and short-lived. This project focuses on developing a new class of ceramic-based thin film materials that are stable in these extreme high temperature harsh environments. The development of these high temperature components will improve sustainability by enabling the deployment of miniaturized sensors, actuators, and other electronic components that can be used to reduce overall energy usage and increase the longevity of complex, expensive high temperature machinery.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: Investigations are being carried out on nanocomposite multilayer thin film structures consisting of oxides, borides, or silicides integrated with Pt-based materials on sapphire, langasite, and Inconel substrates. Rapid materials screening experiments are used to determine the most stable nanocomposite architectures consisting of diffusion barriers, adhesion layers, conducting electrodes, and capping passivation layers. Experiments on the most promising nanocomposite systems focus on probing materials processes such as surface reactivity, interdiffusion, phase formation, oxidation, recrystallization, agglomeration, and roughening. Prototype sensor devices comprised of the ceramic-based nanocomposite films are being evaluated within controlled environment furnaces and small scale turbine engines. The project is educating and training three graduate students and four undergraduates in the areas of ceramic film synthesis, high temperature materials, and characterization of sensor devices. The students are also learning about materials sustainability strategies and technology transfer to the sensor community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Miniature sensors that can withstand the intense heat inside machinery such as turbine engines, combustion burners, power plant boilers, oil and gas drilling machinery, and ceramics manufacturing furnaces can provide critical information to reduce overall energy usage and increase the lifetime of expensive machinery that needs to perform in harsh high temperature environments.  Unfortunately, thin film materials used in the manufacture of sensors often rapidly degrade in most industrial conditions, making the sensors unreliable and short-lived. In this project, stable conductive and insulating thin film materials were developed based on refractory ceramic and Pt-alloy nanocomposites for use in sensors, actuators, and MEMS devices operating over the temperature range 500oC to 1100oC within harsh oxidative environments. 

The project focused on the synthesis, processing, and characterization of several types of high temperature electrical conducting films that are applicable as stable electrodes for sensors, such as wireless microwave acoustic devices, including ZrB2 films, Pt-ZrB2 nanolaminates, and Pt-Si films. It was found that ZrB2 films grown by e-beam evaporation have metallic-like conductivity and remain highly stable in vacuum, but undergo degradation in air as a ZrO2 phase nucleates above 800oC. Pt-ZrB2 nanolaminate structures are more stable in oxidizing environments up to 1100oC. Pt-silicide films grown by e-beam evaporation can be synthesized in either the PtSi, Pt2Si, or Pt3Si phases, and the Pt3Si phase that cannot be formed by conventional solid state thermal reactions has high metallic-like conductivity and a stable equiaxed grain structure that makes it attractive as a conducting electrode. To hinder oxidation effects at high temperature, several insulating capping layers were developed including hexagonal-BN, amorphous Al2O3, and amorphous ZrBCN films. The use of a negative substrate bias during sputtering was found to be especially effective in synthesizing high quality h-BN films. These capping layers extend the operational temperature and lifetimes for these electrode materials. Overall, the thin film materials developed in this project will lead to reliable sensors and actuators that provide a condition-based maintenance and life-cycle management strategy to improve the long-term efficiency and operation lifetime of machinery and materials in harsh high temperature environments.  

The project included the training of 4 PhD graduate students and 15 undergraduates in the areas of thin film deposition (e-beam evaporation, magnetron sputtering, atomic layer deposition), materials analysis (X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy), and sensor device fabrication (lift-off photolithograpy, high temperature processing, and RF measurement techniques). Research results were presented in 15 invited/contributed talks delivered in the U.S. and abroad.  Several community outreach events were carried out that educated K-12 students and the general public about high temperature materials, processes, and sensor devices including an emphasis on energy conservation, efficiency, and sustainability. A particularly successful event involved middle school girls obtaining hands-on experience "Fun with High Temperature Materials - Making Beautiful Glass Beads on a Wire" using a module developed by the American Ceramic Society.
